Andit is not tobe doubted that,  if only we had an adequate discussion of aristocracy by Aristotle in the Politics^ this conclusion would be made abundantly clear^^.  Only then in one circumstance,  and that one realizable in logic rather than in fact®2^ is monarchy right ; when the arete of the King or of his family is so preeminent that it outclasses the arete of all the citisjens put together^^. 
This is Aristotle^s argument in the Politics^ and,  whether or not der read the whole of the Politics or indeed any part of it,  we have no means of knowing.  We only know that Aristotle had tutored Alexander when Alexander was a boy,  from the age of thirteen onwards.  We do not know at all what he taught him.  We do not know at all how much of Aristotle's teaching the boy Alexander understood at the time,  how much he stood,  how much—whether accurately or not—he remembered afterwards.
